reviewText:
Flamebreak is a deep and rewarding game. It blends elements of FTL and The Binding of Isaac in a unique and enjoyable way. I’m not typically someone who enjoys the rogue-like or super hardcore games - which is why I was surprised at how much I’ve enjoyed this game.

When I started off, I quickly died over and over (you only have one life per run). It took me a good 5-10 attempts to really begin making good progress in the game. Each enemy has a unique combat style that requires time to learn and understand. Traversing the “overworld” is a fairly complex task (even though it seems quite trivial at first). Yes - you have to make it to the boss before the “shadow” catches up to you - but there are a lot of hidden elements that aren’t as random as one might think (which I’ll refrain from spoiling in this review).

My next 10 or so playthroughs took me much farther - and I was able to consistently beat the “Phoenix” - although the gods that follow proved to be quite challenging. Despite the large number of playthroughs, I never felt like it was boring or repetitive due to the large number of races, skills, and weapons.

By now, I am able to consistently beat the game on normal - although hard mode remains quite the challenge. I enjoy the daily quest (where everyone gets the same race, skills, weapon, and world) and you compete to see who can beat it the fastest. It’s fun to see how I stack up compared to my friends.

I’ve greatly enjoyed Altitude (another game created by these developers) - where they provided support and additions to the game for free for years. I’m sure Flamebreak will be no different and I’m excited to see what features will be added in the upcoming months.

For $10, I’d highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
This is, at its heart, an arena combat game, with an overworld map where you move between fights.

On the overworld-map, your character picks which of several neighboring areas to explore. (Most areas, involve an arena battle, but sometime you will see an area on the overworld-map that has a town, or bazaar or other non-dangerous location to spend the coins you have accumulated.) Each area of the overworld has a boss on the Northern edge of the map. There is an inherent trade-off between exploring more to find/buy better items with which to face the boss, versus avoiding needless battles which may require you to consume precious health potions. (Health potions are a limited resource, use them with care.) Finally, there is a shadow that slowly advances Northward across the overworld-map, which puts some mild pressure on you to work your way Northward, and prevents you from fully exploring each area of the overworld.

The place where this game shines is in the variety of fights you encounter on your journey. The game features a large number of enemies, each with its own unique attack patterns. Each fight consists of a small number of different types of enemies -- Enemy marksman are typically weak, but when they are protected by foes who lay mines, the fights gets a bit more exciting [at least for a melee character <grin>]. Additionally, many fights have environmental hazards -- like damaging hail-storms that move randomly around the map, or bullets being fired randomly from off-screen.

To tackle these challenges, your character has access to a weapon and three different skills. Your race determines your starting stats and one of your skills. (For instance, Dwarves are slow, but have lots of hit points and deal bonus damage with weapon attacks -- and Dwarves can right-click to stun enemies around then. Alternatively, Faires are very fast and their skills cooldown more quickly, but they have few hit points and do less damage per attack -- and Faires can right-click to teleport instantly in battle.)  The starting weapons are well-designed and each plays very differently -- for instance, swords swing in an arc for strong AOE melee damage, crossbows cripple enemies they hit, slowing their movement. Finally, the game provides a wide variety of active skills, including utility and movement skills -- for those who want to kill foes with weapons -- to high damage spells.

The variety of weapons, races, and skills provides the game with a ton of replayability. At the start of each run, the game randomly generates three possible heroes for you to choose from. This allows you to pick the style of hero you enjoy, but the exact combination of skills will be different each run. Experimenting to get the most out of your combination of skills is a ton of fun. For example, there is a backstab skill that teleports you behind a foe and deals a percentage of your weapon damage. If you have this skill on a burly dwarf with a sword and an AOE stun, then you can backstab into the middle of a group of enemies and stun them all. Alternatively, if you are playing human with a crossbow, you can get more use out of the backstab skill by targeting an isolated foe on the other side of the battle in order to escape a rush of melee attackers.

reviewText:
Flamebreak is a roguelite action-RpG blending twin-stick and MOBA combat gameplay, whilst accompanied by a terrific story, brilliantly told in lyrical prose and voiced quite nicely. I felt as though I'd been playing for only half an hour when, in actuality, over 3 hours had disappeared! In fact, it was only because my index finger was seizing up - and not the fact that it was nearing 3:30 in the morning - that made me stop playing.

The in-battle gameplay is fairly reminiscent of TBoI, but it's far more enjoyable: rather than punishing you for even thinking you could play it, Flamebreak offers a real and rewarding chance at developing your skills and getting to know a bit about the game before dying a bajillion times. It's action-packed and fast-paced, and paying attention to how your enemies deploy attacks is required to overcome and go far. However, this game is not bullet-hell-silly like others similar and I really think that gamers who are usually hesitant to try such games will actually love Flamebreak.

Levels are randomly generated with approximately 25 possible waypoints that keep you moving forward to the boss' lair where success propels you on to the next level. Each waypoint can be a shop of sorts for upgrades, equipment and skills, or a battle. While on the waypoint screen, there are skill abilities you can use that give you a buyer's edge or just to stay ahead of the creeping Shadow that will overtake you if you dally around too long (like FTL's Galactic Federation fleet). In-battle is total arcade gameplay where you may encounter skirmishes, skirmishes with environmental or supernatural hazards bombarding all, gold nabbing and guarding challenges, shrines and temples, even mini-bosses. With numerous races, weapons, skills, battles and bosses randomised every level, not to mention unlockables you get as you become better and better, Flamebreak offers huge replayability and countless hours of white-knuckle fun.

I cannot comment on the use of keyboard+mouse, but I couldn't imagine playing this game with anything other than a controller. With slick, responsive gameplay; clean, bright graphics and pleasing artwork; great story narrated by an attention-grabbing voice; good music and sharp sound effects, I cannot recommend Flamebreak enough, and I feel the regular price is reasonable.

11/ 10

A splendid Action-Roguelike.

This game is my favorite game of the new year. It really captures that plug-and-play procedural action I've been looking for after hundreds of hours of The Binding of Isaac. It offers an immaculate blend of challenge and strategic options that keeps me engaged at the edge of my seat for the whole ~22-40 minute play session. I'm just starting to have hard-mode win-streaks. And even during a -29 lose streak I was having fun discovering character combinations and honing my exploration and gold-spending techniques.

My other favorite thing is the controls. I play mostly with a gamepad and the game offers seamless transition between playing with a controller and playing with keyboard and mouse. Simply move the mouse or joystick and the game snaps to the new control layout. Both options offer very different approaches and are both satisfying to play.

**There are a few issues with balance and (**seemingly) underpowered combos. I couldn't for the life of me get a Human-Sword-Arcane Blast- Meteor character to victory on normal. But in most cases in combination with good item and deity choices you could find the path to victory.
**EDIT** The Devs totally answered my implicit challenge and beat my run on HARD https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lVMBaLvjoXA&feature=youtu.be

Overall this game is a real gem and absolutely should be in your roguelike library.

reviewText:
Borba Recommends
TL:DR at the end, scored 10 / 10 as of 19th April 2016
Borba likes:Genre - A 2D top-down roguelite action rpg, similar to the likes of Binding of Isaac and bundled with different play modes, including daily challenges with online leaderboards. Characters may be customized through race, weapon, skills and items, adding a nice layer of depth to the game, while procedurally generated levels extend longevity.

Replayability - Thanks to the procedurally generated levels that are based on a seed, so players players may share the seed to play the same maps and encounters, and the daily challenges that provide one attempt to score high in the online leaderboards, not to mention unlockable content and achievements, the game provides many hours of challenging fun. There are also custom and hard modes for those wishing to tailor their experience, or face a real challenge.

Narrative - The storyline is presented through artistic painted scrolls, narrated by a lovely voice and with fitting background music. More excerpts are unlocked as players progress and defeat major Bosses.

Gameplay - As a top-down action rpg, the control scheme is twin-stick based and it includes full controller support, being fluid and responsive on both gamepads and keyboard setups. There are hotkeys for skills and items, and a basic attack button, so there aren’t many keys to memorize.

Interface - Even with a certain degree of complexity involving character and item stats, not to mention skill effects and particularities, the whole interface is clean and simple, while still providing players with the ability to mouse over mostly everything in order to reveal a tooltip with all the information and math needed, effectively removing the need to look on wikis or guides for them.

Graphics - Cartoonish and pleasant, with detailed characters and special effects, there is just enough enemy and scenery variation to keep the game interesting for a long time.

Music - From pleasant melodies to engaging battle tunes, the music blends perfectly with the game at any time, and will unlikely feel repetitive or annoying.

Sound - Satisfying, there are plenty of sound effects to go with the weapons and skills the game provides, and none ever felt out of place.

Design - Borba felt curious at the description of “twin-stick meets moba arena combat”, but after playing the game that expression felt just right for the gameplay. It provides a unique experience from similar games, and every feature and mechanic feels well planned and implemented, so that the final result is a fun and original title.

Polish - No major bugs or crashes experienced, just a minor issue that causes frame drops when opening the options screen for the first time after launching the game. Other than that, the game feels and plays like a charm, and so far seems fairly well balanced in terms of difficulty.
Borba dislikes:Nothing!
Borba feels like Flamebreak is a must have title for fans of rogue-lite and / or action rpgs. The small price tag and the amount of replayability you get is amazing, and hopefully more content will be added in the future. It’s also perfect for short sessions, or as a break in between other games, and it even includes twitch integration for live streamers such as himself!

10 / 10

FULL VIDEO REVIEW: https://youtu.be/AikH3fqRNpM
PROS Combines twin-stick and rogue-like/lite elements perfectly to provide satisfying combat with strategic choices.
All abilities feel useful. While some combos obviously work better each ability has individual strengths that give it a unique role.
Skill always trumps luck. RNG will fight you but never kill you unfairly.
Extremely high replay value, 50-100+ hours of gameplay if you enjoy the game and want more.CONSSpirit level takes a long time to level up. Don’t expect to have access to all abilities/weapons/races for a long time.
Sprites are reused a bit too frequently with very little variation. Even most bosses are just resized and recolored normal enemies.Flamebreak takes the Binding of Isaac formula to the next level by combining it with the rogue-like/lite elements of FTL. This combination creates a game that not only requires mechanical skill but also good strategic planning as well. Each time you play the abilities of your character will be randomized in addition to the map being randomized resulting in each playthrough being a completely different experience. It is impossible to overstate how much replayability this game has, even the main game mode will take you quite a while to beat (still working on it myself) and even after that there are challenges and more difficulty modes to keep you interested well into 100+ hours.  If you enjoy the twin-stick genre and are looking for a challenge then Flamebreak is definitely worth a buy.

-You love quick, action packed gameplay that is very well refined.

reviewText:
First off let me just say I got this game for free indirectly by the devs. I think they were just lurking in a popular stream of the game and handed out some keys to a mod who then started private messaging people who asked genuine questions about the game or seemed interested. I guess I just happened to be a lucky one and got a key.

After about 12 hours of play I seem to have 'finished' the game almost completely. I guess I'm sort of done with the game now at level 12 of something like 21 levels [last unlock is at level 21 I think]. You gain leveling EXP, called 'Insight', by clearing a zone/world. Further leveling would reward me with new playable races, weapons, and abilities/spells being added to the pool. Missing the 2 hardest [?] achievements which require a bit of focus [clear hard mode 5 times in a row, get 40 favour with Furere]. I've beat all the gods at least once and looped the world once just to try it.


Anyway I'll try to give my half cent on the game:

-Visually the game isn't too appealing at first sight and many people seem to compare it to flash games which honestly doesn't seem too far off. Just going by the screenshots on the steam store page I honestly wouldn't give this game too much thought, but after playing ~12 hours the visuals have somewhat grown on me and I now find them appealing. Enemy types are easily identifiable just by looking at them. The fields are randomly generated and have obstructions placed in them which can't be walked over but can still be attacked over. Some of these, especially on the snow levels, can be a bit hard to see during combat. All hitboxes and AoE's seem very clear, for the ones you aren't too sure about the game let's you see their AoE by mousing over the skill icon at any time. A small iffy I got with the fields, the forest one in particular, is that if you push an enemy to the edge of the arena then they can get completely covered up and hidden by the tree's that decorate the edge of the screen and it has gotten me hit a few times because I can't see their animations.

-Audio is pretty chill. I was quite content just listening to the BGM instead of putting on my own music, which is my usual opposite for games. Sound doesn't seem to play a big part in the game at all except for some hazard zones and knowing when things will appear from outside the screen [boulders mainly]. SFX is enjoyable except for when you have heaps of summons/helpers on the field helping you, then the sound of them bashing at things is quite overwhelming and unpleasant.

-Gameplay is the main appeal of this game for me. All races, weapons, and skills that I have unlocked so far seem to be viable for a successful run in some way and seem to be quite balanced. On each run the world also selects 5 sets of items from ~10 you can buy in shops which have stat boosts and special effects which usually carry your run. Every one of them has a use, although some are definitely more useful than others. Enemies, hazards, fields, bosses, shops, gold gains, etc, all seem fair and balanced in their own way. Even though the game is tagged as a rogue-lite, it is quite forgiving with being hit by giving you plenty of HP, it's possible to do an entire run without being hit. Every time you finish combat without being hit it says 'Flawless!' which stacks up with every flawless clear. Although this doesn't seem to add any direct benefit to the game it does feel good knowing you've fought X amount of battles without being damaged. I've gotten to the point where I can clear just about everything [except for arcane traps god I hate them, they're not even deadly it's like they're just made to break your combo] without being hit.

There are multiple game modes you can select which vary the difficulty of the game in some way. In normal mode you have a choice of 3 characters which are randomly generated. If you don't feel like doing a randomly generated character you can just choose custom mode and make your own from scratch, but receive less insight during the run in exchange. Hard mode just hands you a randomly generated character and you take 50% more damage, but double your insight gains. Then there is nightmare mode which is the same as hard mode, but forces you to loop the world in exchange for triple insight gains. There are also daily options for all of these which give everyone the exact same character loadout, world seed, etc, for you to compete on a leader board.

Not sure what else I can say about the game. I found it quite enjoyable. The challenge was definitely there. I guess I was pleasantly surprised by the game and stuck around longer than I initially thought I would. I would definitely recommend this game, but I personally probably wouldn't buy it even after watching other people play it and even if $10 USD isn't much. I might buy it if it was on sale but it wouldn't be high on my priorities. The game was good sure, but it didn't really feel memorable or anything like that. The most memorable thing for me was the little rhyming intro and outro screens that appear before every zone and after every boss. It just didn't feel very different from many other rogue-lite experiences for me.

I'll just say it again. It's enjoyable and not too brutal in difficulty, but it really doesn't feel like anything new. Even though I say that, I still recommend this game.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic on just about every point. There's a lot of variety in skills and attributes for you to level up, and most importantly, every thing seems useful. There was no single stat or skill that I felt like I'd never use, which is an uncommon feeling.
The progress feels very nice, and the gameplay is a lot of fun. Challenging, highly skill-based, interesting and feels good.
The perspective is weird, but that's alright.
The story is very interesting - the world building is fantastic - and the voice acting is surprisingly good.

Definitely a solid Roguelike. If you like Binding of Issac or Rouge Legacy or other similar games, it is absolutely worth adding to your collection.

reviewText: I enjoyed playing this game. It is rare these days that a game makes good use of rogue-like elements, rather than just adding them for the sake of it. The perma-death is not just added to increase gameplay time, but because every run is unique. There is a good amount of weapons, races and abilities to choose from and all of them really affect the gameplay. There are even multiple final bosses! As a result it has a good replay value and makes every run feel different. Furthermore, the randomness in the game is well balanced. Rarely you get a run that simply isn't possible due to bad RNG. The only downside to this game is that various abilities, races and god powers are clearly better than others, which results in you re-rolling characters several times if you want a better chance at winning the game.

reviewText:
This game controls as you expect it to when you move or use a power. The auto lock on system for gamepad control works great to target your attacks and powers, and it's easy to switch to the target you want usually. This game is also based on player skill and not luck. Every death so far has felt like it was my fault of skill, or a power/weapon selection that wasn't ideal in combo with my play style.

For this type of game that's high praise.

Your character has 4 powers and is made up of the following:
Race. Each race/species has slightly different stats and a unique power. For instance Humans have an ability which summons a 1 hit to kill ally that can distract and attack enemies, while the Dwarf has an ability to slam the ground and stun all nearby enemies.

Weapon. Each weapon mostly just attacks (which is another power) but at least one, the spear, you will throw if you wait a few second between attacks. There's a fair variety between melee and ranged weapons.

Abilities. There's a set of powers that you get two of. These have a range of effects. One throws a flame wave out, another throws out a stun that passes through enemies, and there's one that summons tiny skeletons holding bombs that seek out and explode on enemies. Of course there's more than just those 3 powers.

You start with 3 randomly selected characters with the above to choose from normally, though I just unlocked the ability to choose a combination myself at the price of only recieving half Spirit" rewards which builds up and levels over games to unlock more races

reviewText:
TL;DR 8/10

Flamebreak really surprised me.
If you were to go into it looking at the pictures or the trailer (now updated and much better, great job guys!), you'd probably pass it up. Even once you reach the menu and do the initial stage, it doesn't scream anything special.

But please, give it a shot. Once you get rolling it's a lot of fun. You're basically entering a bunch of arenas, each with random enemies and sometimes battlefield effects to dodge (Meteors, traps, etc). Think isaac with no treasure rooms and a large focus on shops and finding complete set pieces.

If you like dual stick shooters, or real time roguelikes, definitely check this one out.

EDIT: bumped it up a bit in score. Really starts fleshing out and having more of that craziness you come to look for in these games once you get a bit into it.
